Buying Guide: How to Choose the Best Air Fryers

Focus on fit, performance, and cleanup to compare the best options for home use.

For most homes, a 5–6 quart model hits the sweet spot for capacity, price, and counter space.

1–2 people

2–4 qt (compact, cheaper)

Families

5–6 qt (best all-around choice)

Meal prep / big households

dual basket or 7+ qt

Choose the right size
Household size Recommended size Why
1–2 people 2–4 qt Faster cooking, takes less space
3–4 people 5–6 qt Best balance for most homes
5+ people 7+ qt or dual basket Fewer batches, easier full meals
Single basket vs dual basket

Single basket

  • Cheaper
  • Simpler
  • Best for beginners

Dual basket

  • Cook two foods at once
  • Better for families
  • Costs more and takes more space
Price vs value
Price range What to expect
$60–$120 Basic controls, less consistent airflow
$120–$200 Best value: even cooking, solid build
$200–$300 Dual baskets and convenience features
Features that actually matter
  • Capacity — determines how often you cook in batches
  • Airflow power — affects crispiness and speed
  • Basket coating — makes cleaning easier and helps it last longer

Features you can ignore

  • Dozens of presets
  • App connectivity
  • Fancy touchscreens
Common mistakes to avoid
  • Buying too small "to save space"
  • Overpaying for features you won't use
  • Ignoring basket cleaning and maintenance
Who should skip an air fryer?
  • Large households cooking full meals in one batch
  • Anyone who already uses a convection oven daily
Quick takeaways
  • Choose size first: 5–6 qt covers most homes without taking over the counter.
  • Single baskets are simplest; go dual only if you cook full meals at once.
  • Prioritize airflow power and easy-clean coatings over extra presets.

How We Picked

We analyze review data, specs, and pricing, then apply editorial checks to keep comparisons consistent.

  • Review data trends across top-rated models
  • Specs, capacity, and usability for everyday home use
  • Editorial checks to keep comparisons consistent

FAQ

What does the “Best overall” tag mean?

We use “Best overall” for the option that performs well across the most important factors—core performance, ease of use, build quality, and price—without major trade-offs.

What does the “Best value” tag mean?

“Best value” highlights the pick that delivers the most for the money: strong performance and reliability at a lower price, even if it skips premium extras.

What matters most when comparing models?

Prioritize capacity, airflow power for crisping, and a durable basket coating; presets and app features rarely change day-to-day results.
